markdownRemark.html:
Score: 95

marketwatch.com  (WEB - en-US)

A site covering global financial markets with news, analysis, data, and investment tools.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The site is owned by Dow Jones & Co., a unit of News Corp., a publicly traded international publishing conglomerate controlled by Rupert Murdoch that owns multiple media outlets, including The Wall Street Journal, Barron’s, and The Times of London.

The site runs advertisements.

Content

The top of the Marketwatch homepage features real-time data charts showing information on the Dow Jones Index, the Nasdaq, the S&P 500, as well as gold and oil prices, futures, and international market metrics. Next to these trackers, the site publishes headlines under the “Latest News” section. Below, the page is divided into “Need to Know” articles: Most Popular, Trending Videos, Markets, Investing, Economy & Politics, Personal Finance, Retirement, and Real Estate. The Moneyist section answers reader questions about “inheritance, tipping, weddings, re-gifting, or any tricky money issues relating to family and friends.” SectorWatch publishes articles on the “latest trends and developments across the 11 sectors of the S&P 500,” including Healthcare Goods & Services, and Technology.

Marketwatch notably cites current market performances within articles. These appear beside the names of publicly traded companies and market indexes, stocks, and bonds. For example, a July 2018 article titled “Starbucks joins MDonald’s, IKEA, Seattle and Vancouver in ban on plastic straws” reported  that “Starbucks SBUX, -1.81%  is the latest company to ban the use of plastic straws. “ When readers mouse over the name Starbuck’s, a pop-up appears showing the current price of that company’s stock, a chart indicating its live market performance, and related news headlines.

Transparency

Articles give the writer’s name, title, and generally a social media handle and an email address, as well as a list of articles that reporter has written. Most bylines for authors who are not on the Marketwatch staff include contact or biographical information. The site does not provide a masthead or information about its leadership. MarketWatch did not respond to two NewsGuard emails asking about the site’s failure to provide information on those in charge.

The “Newsroom Roster” page features only a general email address and New York street address. Marketwatch.com makes clear its affiliation to Dow Jones. Advertisements are clearly labeled.

History

Marketwatch was founded in 1995 as DBC Online by journalist and entrepreneur Larry Kramer, and initially funded by CBS. The site launched in 1997 and went public in 1999. It was among the first news websites heavily to feature video news. Dow Jones & Co. acquired Marketwatch in 2005 for about $520 million.

Disclosure: NewsGuard co-CEO Gordon Crovitz is a former executive vice president of Dow Jones & Co.

Written by:
Anna-Sophie Harling

Edited by:
Amy Westfeldt Joyce Purnick
